story:
Short Summary

My name is Ian Clontz and I run Historia Photography in Columbia County, FL . All too often I feel like I could be doing more to give back to people in my community. Last year when I discovered Help-Portrait, a non-profit that encourages photographers from all over the world to go out and photograph and frame a single photo for underprivileged families, I knew I had found my outlet to do some good in this world. 

Last year I teamed up with a non-profit daycare, Happy House, in Lake City Florida and we managed to photograph over 30 families, a little less than half of which are single parent homes. It went so well, we are making this an annual event! This year we are attempting to photograph even more families, as well as donate a portion of the proceeds to Happy House, and we need your help! On December 5th, International Portrait Day, we will have the opportunity to affect positive change in the lives and hearts of some amazing families.

What We Need 

The $3000 I am attempting to raise will go toward :

1. Printing/framing 1 photo per family.
2. Refreshments for the families as they wait to have their photo taken.
3. Discs/flash drives, so the families can have access to all of the photos taken on Dec. 5th.
4. Whatever funds are left over will be donated to Happy House.

The Impact

By donating to this cause you are helping to put a positive emphasis on core family values. Every family should have a portrait of their loved ones hanging in their home. Donate today to help a lot of wonderful families!

Perks for Donating

Historia Photography will be offering discounts* on photo shoots for your family & friends! The more you donate the more you save!

*excludes weddings and/or events & only redeemable in central/north central Florida (or the discount can be transferred to someone residing in central/north central Florida)

story:
From our early days, Tight Club has always wanted to provide an experience that was unlike any other gym or studio. We wanted to build an active community of people who enjoyed coming together for a great workout, and to create lasting, accountable relationships that centered about fitness.

Using every inch of the Eastside community of Strathcona in Vancouver—our home hood—we made movement and ‘working out’ accessible to people who wanted to sweat, but hated the traditional gym setting. ​We've done pretty much every non-workout-workout that's ever been conceived. From escaping a zombie apocalypse to hurdling the living dead. ​

Our current home at The Coach House has been the hub for all things Tight Club since 2013. This is where Keighty works with her personal training clients, where the run club meets up, and where loud music pushes Tight Clubbers through their hour-long HIIT workouts at all hours of the day.

The need to find a permanent home dedicated to all our Tight Club antics is becoming more and more apparent. Our classes are starting to spill out into the alleyway and we're only able to apologize to the neighbours so many times for cranking ‘Bubble Butt’ at 6:30 am.

When we found a space that would allow us to keep Tight Club in its original hood, we knew it was time to take the leap and give ourselves a more permanent home. Now all we need are some funds to help build out the new space.

With the $30,000 we’re aiming to raise, we’re doing a ground up build: stripping everything down and building it back up to provide all the amenities you need to get from your sweat life to your work life in a snap. 

  

  


We jam out hard; so we’ll be needing some sound proofing to keep our bass at bay. We'll need showers to clean up our sweaty bodies before we head to work and we'll need some pretty decent floors to keep our bodies (and joints) happy. We'll also need a welcoming community space so you can drink your juice and catch up with your crew before and after you get TIGHT.

     

    

We’re dedicated to making this space as full service as possible to suit the lifestyle of our crew and give them every reason to spend even more time with us. A squad that sweats together, stays together.

Flooring: 15k | We'll be providing high end Teraflex Athletic Flooring adequate for both yoga, high intensity, and strength training classes. We'll also have polished concrete floor in the front and back spaces.

Showers / Bathroom: 20k | We'll be digging ‘er up so you can wash it down. Trenching, plumbing, tiling and air flow engineerings are included in this cost.

HVAC System: 20k | To keep the good times coming in and the bad smells going out, this system will be installed from scratch.

Fitness Equipment: 15k | Lots more gear to get TIGHT with. A complete TRX system, squat racks, free weights, skipping ropes, bosu balls, slam balls and more.

Electrical: 15k | When the space is bright, your future is TIGHT!

*We know the above adds up to more than $30,000 (where we have set our goal). All the funds we raise will be used to help offset construction costs of this buildout.

We're proud of being #TIGHTPIMPS, and wanted to extend the opportunity to our contributors to wear their Tight Club pride. To commemorate finding our first home and to celebrate YOUR contribution to the studio build, we've designed limited edition graphics for the perks we're preparing.AND, because having your name on something that creates community, stands for connection and is fuelled by movement, we've added in some higher price point perks where your contribution will be seen and celebrated every damn day. 

Plus, check that steal of a deal on the annual membership -- serious #tightpimps will be hopping on that FAST. Get 'em while they're hot!

Tight Club is more than just a fitness business. We’re a crew who looks after one another whether we’re in the studio, in our living rooms, or at the club. The build of this studio is going to provide a home for our community; a place for the tightness to grow in both the workouts and sweaty pursuits, and a venue for our friendships to grow stronger.

Started through a commitment of creating a sense of inclusivity and belonging so that everyone feels like a part of the family, we’re the kind of folk to get up at the crack of dawn to cheer our crew through half marathons, to show up and get bendy when they teach yoga classes, or get down on the dance floor when they host fundraisers. The space simply means more opportunities to do THAT: support one another in living the tight life.

Our people are what matter most. Point blank. From tight pimps to team members - they’re at the center of everything we do.

Tight Club was started by Keighty Gallagher, whose vision was to make fitness accessible to her creative counterparts. 3 years later, Keighty has built up a small team of run and swim coaches who have found strength and leadership in the group and are sharing it with their communities.

Tight Club is visually backed up by creative director, Henry Barros, who designed Tight Club’s signature ‘TC’ logo and has been with the crew since day one. Henry’s the silent strong man helping wherever he can.

Kat Holmes and Kevin Lionais lead the run crews. Kat and Kevin gravitated towards the Tight Club community (and us towards them) because of their desire to move, and their keenness to have loads of fun while doing it.

We’ve also got a small team (with a lot of heart) who are supporting this campaign; from social media aficionados to writers to video crews - and everything in between.

Pick a perk and wear your Tightness with pride OR give us a shout out and share what we’re up to with your community. Word of mouth is endlessly powerful and it’s how we got our start. The more chatter, the better.

Share some love on Twitter: @tightclubtweets

Give us a double tap on Instagram: @tightclub

Like what you see on Facebook: Tight Club Athletics

We’re insanely grateful for your support, and cannot wait to welcome you into the Tight Club studio in Winter 2015!

story:
S obzirom na veliku podršku koju smo dobili u prvih par dana, te početni cilj kojem se naveliko približavamo, odlučili smo našu kampanju odvesti korak dalje. Ciljamo prikupiti dodatnih 2000$, kako bismo i najmlađima pokazali da su Križevci mali grad velikih mogućnosti i jednakih prilika za sve.

Svi prvašići grada Križevaca (razred po razred) će dobit besplatan izlet u Choco Bar gdje će imati priliku kušati Hedonine proizvode i upoznati se s Hedonom i njenim zaposlenicima, a za uspomenu će dobiti čokoladno srce napravljeno posebno za njih.

 

Mali grad velikih mogućnosti

Dok mnogi u potrazi za poslom bježe u velike gradove, jedan gradić u blizini Zagreba dokaz je da mali grad ne mora značiti i malo mogućnosti.

Jeste li ikada posjetili Križevce? Taj je grad po mnogočemu poseban, no jedna priča u sebi krije dodatnu čaroliju. U srcu Križevaca nalazi se čokolaterija Hedona - društveno poduzeće koje je osnovala ''Udruga invalida Križevci'' s ciljem da otvori radna mjesta i ubrza integraciju u društvo upravo za osobe s invaliditetom.
Hedona trenutno broji 9 zaposlenih, od kojih su 6 osobe s invaliditetom.

  • Josip, jedan od prvih zaposlenika Hedone

U današnje vrijeme posao je teško pronaći, a još je teže naći onaj koji će za nas značiti više od samog radnog mjesta. Iako svatko od nas mora pronaći način kako će zaraditi za život, za neke je to poseban izazov. Najmanje privilegirana skupina u ovom smislu su osobe s invaliditetom. Gotovo polovica njih koji žive u Hrvatskoj su u radno aktivnoj dobi, no bez posla i prilike za dostojanstven život.

 

Choco Bar - Hedonin najnoviji projekt

Otvaranje Choco Bara planirano je do kraja 2017. godine, a omogućit će zapošljavanje još 5 osoba, od kojih su 2 osobe s invaliditetom.

Choco Bar biti će mjesto za okupljanje i uživanje u raznovrsnoj ponudi vrhunskih proizvoda križevačke čokolaterije. Imat ćete priliku kušati brojne čokolade i praline, domaće kolače i najfiniju toplu čokoladu.

  • želimo da naš Choco Bar bude mjesto uvažavanja različitosti koje će okupljati sve ljubitelje čokolade
  • želimo otvoriti nova radna mjesta i biti pozitivan primjer drugima
  • želimo nastaviti proizvoditi čokolade i praline za još širu publiku

Grad Križevci je Choco Baru dodijelio prostor u novootvorenom Tehološkom parku, dok je uređenje prostora osigurano iz EU fondova, ali kako bi naša usluga bila savršena potrebna su nam dodatna sredstva za financiranje opreme, stoga smo odlučili pokrenuti crowdfunding kampanju.


Za vrhunske slastice potrebna je i vrhunska oprema

Oduvijek smo pridavali pažnju kvaliteti naših proizvoda i usluga. Za opremanje kuhinje i šanka prema našim visokim standardima potrebno nam je dodatnih 5 000$. Sredstva ćemo iskoristiti za kupnju pećnice i točionika za vruću čokoladu. ​​​​

Timeline 

Razlog, dva za podržati:

  • pružate podršku osobama s invaliditetom
  • sudjelujete u njihovom uključivanju u širu zajednicu i društvo
  • omogućujete ostvarenje njihovog prava na rad, koje je bitan uvjet ravnopravnosti
  • pomažete mijenjati sliku o osobama s invaliditetom, razbijati predrasude o njihovim mogućnostima

Podržite nas donacijom, a zauzvrat Vam nudimo širok spektar Hedoninih čokoladnih čarolija!

  • 50 gramske   - mliječna/tamna/ bijela čokolada
  • 100 gramske - mliječna čokolada s brusnicama i lješnjacima / tamna čokolada s 71% kakaa s brusnicama i lješnjacima/ bijela čokolada s brusnicama i lješnjacima

Zajedno s Križevačkom udrugom Pivara osmislili smo posebno “čokoladno” pivo, a s Križevačkim čipkaricama čipkano srce  samo za naše podržavatelje.​

Osim donacijom možete nam pomoći tako da:

  • podijelite vijest o kampanji na svojim društvenim mrežama
    (Facebook, Twitter)
  • podijelite vijest o kampanji dok ste na kavi s prijateljima

​Svaki like i share puno nam znači, a svakom novom gostu Choco Bara garantiramo vrhunsku uslugu i najfinije slastice pripremljene s mnogo ljubavi.  

Hvala!

story:
All Aboard! 

With the help of 85 backers, I have secured a spot on the Millennial Trains Project. Thank you all, from the bottom of my heart. Any additional contributions will be a donation to the Millennial Trains Project. 
If you would like to continue to support Feeding The Giant, please reach out to me directly at devinpeek@gmail.com. 


Feeding The Giant

Our country’s increasing wealth gap is having massive impacts on our food workers’ rights, specifically in the restaurant industry. This project will take an in-depth look at workers’ stagnant wages, inability for upward advancement, and lack of paid sick leave, from both the employee and employers sides of this struggle. Through video, photography, audio, and illustration, Feeding The Giant hopes to bring these stories to life through a human-centered lens.  


I'm Devin. 

I'm a designer and photographer. Growing up falling asleep to epic bedtime sagas, listening to talk radio about foreign lands, and watching documentaries about interesting characters, I've always been passionate about people, cultures and stories. At IDEO, I work with a multidisciplinary team to tell some of our most complex and challenging stories including  redefining the cafeteria experience for San Francisco students, improving the voting system in Los Angeles County, and tackling daunting societal problems through a conceptual project called Designs On—. I love the challenge of exploring complex issues through the eyes of those at the core.


Our Food System is Broken:

With over 11 million workers, the restaurant industry is one of the fastest growing sectors of the US economy. Unfortunately, the backbone of this industry - the food workers themselves - have been left out of the economic boom, unable to see the fruits of their labor in an industry that could be pushing them toward a brighter future. Instead, many employees face dismal working conditions, such as low or unpaid work, lack of internal promotion, non-exist benefits and sexual harassment. The federal minimum wage has been locked at $2.13 hour for tipped workers for the past twenty-three years, dating back to 1991, and this forces tipped employees to rely solely on gratuities to make ends meet, an antiquate form of economy that in post-Civil War America was called, "a cancer in the breast of democracy,” and in contemporary America has been proven to fuel sexual harassment and racial discrimination.

Many organizations are currently fighting for restaurant workers' rights, including ROC United, Fight for 15, Food Chain Workers Alliance, UNITED HERE - Food Service Division, and Brandworkers International. These organizations and many more have been massive inspirations to me. Feeding The Giant aims to help bring the silenced voices of our country’s restaurant workforce to the forefront because this is an issue that affects us all.


About Millennial Trains Project

Millennial Trains Project (MTP) is an award-winning 501(c)3 non-profit organization that leads transcontinental train journeys for young innovators to explore America’s new frontiers. Feeding the Giant is an officially-approved campaign for MTP's August 2016 journey.


The Journey

"Change"
August 1 - 7

Pittsburgh > Chicago > Kansas City > Albuquerque > Los Angeles

At each stop, there will be a local showcase, featuring local innovation and where the city is headed from a creative development perspective. Then, I'll have 5-6 hours to advance the project by meeting with local restaurant workers, owners, and change advocates. 

In addition to on-train discussions, leadership development, and design-thinking workshops, engagements with local leaders will focus on the communities we visit, and MTP participant projects will focus on opportunities and challenges that participants themselves are seeking to address on a national scale.


Other Ways You Can Help

  • If you like what you see, share! Follow along on Instagram, Twitter, and at feedingthegiant.com. 
  • Know someone who would be interested in helping out or speaking up? Send them my way @devin_peek or devinpeek@gmail.com.

story:
CHSR is a campus-based community radio station based in Fredericton, NB, Canada. We need your support to make the next year better than ever!

Let’s Go Farther!

2014 was a stressful year for us. We persevered and overcame -- thanks in great part to your generous donations for last year’s campaign -- and we turned it around, made things better than ever.

This year, we’d like to ask for your help again. We have more modest funding goal, but no less modest an ambition!

What This Campaign For?

Last year, we had a serious problem: water damage forced us to gut and rebuild three of four studios. It took a year to recover (and there are still a few things to install), but we decided to cash in some long-term project money and top-up what was spent to do more.

This year, the studios are entering full operation, and we are surging forward, but...

Our major source of funding is from the universities, and enrollment is declining. So, just as we are on the rise and doing more, we have less money to work with. We stretch and we save, and we put up with equipment that was outdated 5 years ago. We invested in people, and we’re dedicated to that.

But things are getting to be a bit more difficult: headphones are wearing out, more microphones are needed, our computers are starting to fail. We can’t afford to replace that stuff, but we need to.

That’s where you help!

What's the Money For?

Money raised in this campaign will allow us to do the necessary upkeep and let us reach farther. It will allow us to keep our staff and improve our quality. It allows us to expand things like Sessions, remote event coverage and audio editing. It will help us reach out further into the community and on campus, and help build our other means of fundraising.

Your money will mean we can get needed microphones, headphones, computers and other vital equipment. It means we sound better, our volunteers can host better shows, and we can breathe a bit of space into our budget.

What If You Don’t Get It?

Then, we manage, as best we can. We don’t buy the necessary equipment. We limit the things we do, drop some of our plans, and really worry about the bottom line. (The budget really is that tight!) We don’t want to have to choose between doing things with people and  the proper equipment to do them with, but if we have to, we will.

Sessions? What are Sessions?

Yes! Prior to our problems in 2014, we were in full swing producing a series called Sessions @ CHSR. Bands from all over -- touring bands and local bands -- joined a host in Studio D for a combination of interview and performance. We’ve gotten some spectacular recordings from that series -- original songs before release, alternative takes, stripped-down and acoustic versions. It’s been great fun getting to know the bands and finding out what their creative inspiration comes from, and what life in a band is like.

But when we gutted Studio D as a result of the water damage, those stopped. We recorded  71 sessions in just over 3  years, and we were looking forward to continuing the weekly schedule.

And now: we’re back!

The Sessions EP Series

In fact, we’re so dedicated to Sessions -- and they produce such great tracks! -- that we want to create a “best of” compilation for next year.

That compilation will be one of the rewards for helping us.

… and the more help you give, the better we can make the compilation!

Here’s how it works: you buy in on the base level of the EP -- either from the pledge level or by adding on to your pledge.

That EP will be compiled one year from now, and contain 4 of the best tracks from our Sessions over the last year.

BUT:

The better we do, the more effort we can put toward Sessions, and the more tracks we want to include!

So, as we do better, more tracks get added, until we fill out an EP with 9 tracks.

Then, we add a second EP. See where we’re going? The more people donate, the better it gets!

We’ll also start pulling tracks from the 71 sessions we’ve already done.

These albums will all be strictly digital, but if we get enough support, we’ll add an add-on option to buy a physical CD.

CD Update!

We're up to 5 tracks on the EP -- and almost the 6th!

How Does The Sessions@CHSR EP Grow?

The basic EP starts at 4 tracks. Another track will be added to the EP at $500 earned on the campaign, and at every $500 after that.

So:

$0 - 4-track EP -- DONE!

$500 - 5-track EP -- DONE!

$1000 - 6-track EP -- ALMOST THERE!

$1500 - 7-track EP -- WE CAN DO IT!

$2000 - 8-track EP -- I KNOW YOU WANT IT..

$2500 - 9-track EP -- THIS WOULD BE AWESOME!

Note that this will continue to climb regardless of how many people actually select the EP perk. So, even if you know people who aren't interested in it, encourage them to donate, both for our benefit and yours!

At $2500, we've made our goal. BUT if we get there, we'll announce plans for stretch goals to get another EP, and then another one after that, and.. Well, we'll see, after that!


How Can I Help? I don’t have much money…

It doesn’t take a lot of money to help out -- every dollar really counts! -- but what we really need is to amplify our voice.

Let your friends know about the station. They might not be aware, but they’ll appreciate that you told them.

Tell us that you love the station. Positive feedback is encouraging, and we’ll highlight your feedback to show others how much awesome we do.

Share it on Social Media. You’ve got a phone and a finger. You can share our needs with everyone you know -- even if they don’t live here, because we broadcast online and podcast.

What if you get all your money? Are you done?

Heck no! We’ve got lots of projects we’d like to fund, beyond just the equipment we desperately need.

Some examples:

  • An improved streamer! We need to change to a better system, an MP3 streamer that plays on more devices, but we’ll need to pay a monthly service fee for that, and get a new computer.

  • Music Database enhancements! We track every album that comes into the station, but the system needs big updates. We’d also like to take digital submissions, but we can’t afford a system to manage those yet.

  • The Sleeving Project! Speaking of music, we have over 10,000 albums and over 60,000 CDs! But: we’re running out of space! To bridge the gap to the purely digital future, we’re transferring large jewel cases into sleeves which take up ⅓ the space. But that’s a lot of sleeves..

  • Sessions @ CHSR video stream! We’d like to invite you to our live audience for Sessions, by letting you watch online!

  • Workshops! We’d like to offer workshops for members and the general public, but we can’t afford the money or time to host them. From advice on writing for radio to audio editing to producing radio dramas, we'd love to talk about it all!

  • Shake ‘n’ Bake! We put on several great concerts over the years, but as money becomes tight we have to focus on other things to make things work. If we had more donations, we could give ourselves a break and put on a wicked-sized concert!

  • Raises for Staff! The staff work for a very minimal salary, and we haven’t been able to give a real raise for years -- barely even cost of living, when at all.

So, what is CHSR? CHSR is Radio...

For 54 years, we’ve been bringing radio -- in many forms -- to the Fredericton area. It started with very local, wired broadcasts to our current transmitter reaching the Capital region and the world through our live Internet stream and podcasting.

We are a voice for the alternative. We provide exposure for under-appreciated and under-represented music -- both from around the world and very importantly from right here in the city. We invite hosts to produce works based on issues and entertainment that matters to them, things often overlooked in the mainstream.

CHSR is also Campus

We’re located in the Student Union Building at the University of New Brunswick in Fredericton. We started as a student club of UNB, and have expanded to embrace St Thomas University as part of our study base as well.

But our campus connections run even deeper: students from every school in the city are welcome to join us, and a great part of our audience is made up of eager students looking for something beyond the mainstream -- or looking to have a voice in their community.

CHSR is definitely Community, too

We grew beyond just a student club quite a while ago, and we are committed to providing the whole community of Fredericton with a reflection of the great things this city has to offer -- and the areas where we can collectively change for the better.

Through regular programs like The Lunchbox (a daily community events and interview show) and Fredericton This Week (a weekly half-hour calendar of events), we celebrate the goings-on in our community. Through great locally-focused music shows like Instant Breakfast and Homemade Jams, we give bands a chance to get great exposure, and music fans the great music they crave.

We give a strong counter-argument to the uninformed opinion that there’s “nothing going on in this city”.

We give non-profit organizations, up-and-coming musicians, emerging artists and interesting people a chance to talk about their passions, and for everyone to create compelling programming.

Contribute to Your Community.

Contribute to Your Community Radio!

Thanks!

Add-Ons

You want to challenge a show, but you want the shirt or the EP? Or you want an ad and a t-shirt? No problem! Just increase your pledge to include the add-on:
  • +$15 EP
  • +$15 T-Shirt*
  • +$5 Vinyl Slip Mat*
  • +$5 Postcards*

(* If you can pick these up, there's no delivery charge. Otherwise, add +$10 for delivery of the T-shirt, +$5 for delivery of the vinyl slip mat or postcards. If you are getting a t-shirt AND other things, you'll only be paying +$10 total.)

story:
Hello,

My name is Amanda Abraham. I have come here to this site to attempt to raise urgently needed funds. I was involved in an altercation back in April 2012 when an ex-partner was physically, verbally and emotionally abusive towards me. Scared and confused, I fought back. He showed no signs of relenting even when I called police, not knowing what else to do in the situation at the time. In an unfortunate twist of fate, the police took me to jail that night, where I subsequently spent 2 1/2 days in jail.

Due to lack of my ability to afford proper legal representation, I accepted a plea bargain for a reduced sentence in which I was able to avoid jail time by completing anger management therapy.

Prior to this incident, I have had a clean background record and no history of incidents of violence towards others in any way. My friends and associates know me as a very passive human being, so the idea that I was ordered to take anger management courses (while my ex gets off scot-free!) is beyond absurd. As you can imagine, this incident and charge has affected negatively in a great number of ways, such as my inability to obtain stable employment due to a no longer clean criminal background record due to this incident.

I have journeyed back and forth from Chicago to DeKalb (where the incident originally took place)- 7 times, due to extensions needed in order for me to locate a facility that offered these state-certified courses, and figure out how to pay for them.

At this point I have completed these course hours as required. The catch, however, is that the Oakbrook, Illinois office will not provide me with the certificate to present to court until ALL my fees for the course have been paid. The breakdown is as follows:

The courses are $140 per week for 2-hour sessions for a total of 11 weeks. 

I have already paid $980 (PLUS $360 in initial court fees, not to mention gas and transportation to and from DeKalb).

I still need a total of $560 before I can get the certificate to present to court and avoid jail time. My next (and hopefully last) court date for this case is October 3rd, 2014, which is just over two weeks from now.

My wages as a housekeeper will not permit me to pay for the remainder of these classes on my own I have stayed at various friends places around Chicago (since I have no family which I can rely on to stay with- I have moved a total of 8 times since this case began).

I don't like to ask for handouts, but certainly don't look down on others who do. I am very non-materialistic and the type of person who believes in sharing. I've made myself broke before by giving a person on the street the last of the money I had, just because I thought they might need it more. I have had various health and financial struggles throughout the years, but I still believe in helping others. I'm the kind of person that believes in being humble and making things work with what you've got.

With that being said, I hope that my story was concise enough for everyone to understand. If anyone would like to know more details about the situation, or perhaps have a similar story they can relate to, I'm willing to communicate.

Even if I am not able to raise all the money, I can only hope that others will be kind, understanding and supportive of the fact that this has been extremely difficult to manage, and share my story with others as an indicator of one of the worst-case-scenarios one can get into when they stay with an abusive partner for too long.

Please know that any funds accumulated to this site will ONLY be used for this purpose, and I can provide proof as needed. Anything extra that I might accumulate will be used for immediate expenses such as food and shelter 

Thank you to all in advance, your love and support are very much appreciated.

Sincerely,

Amanda A. Abraham

I've made myself broke before by giving a person on the street the last of the money I had, just because I thought they might need it more. I have had various health and financial struggles throughout the years, but I still believe in helping others. I'm the kind of person that believes in being humble and making things work with what you've got.
With that being said, I hope that my story was concise enough for everyone to understand. If anyone would like to know more details about the situation, or perhaps have a similar story they can relate to, I'm willing to communicate. 
Even if I am not able to raise all the money, I can only hope that others will be kind, understanding and supportive of the fact that this has been extremely difficult to manage, and share my story with others as an indicator of one of the worst-case-scenarios one can get into when they stay with an abusive partner for too long.
Please know that any funds accumulated to this site will ONLY be used for this purpose, and I can provide proof as needed. Anything extra that I might accumulate will be used for immediate expenses such as food and shelter 
Thank you to all in advance, your love and support are very much appreciated.
Sincerely,
Amanda A. Abraham

story:
Tel Aviv's best party organizers, Maya Sharon and OneDay are throwing a party at the Q HOTEL to raise money for projects renovating Holocaust survivor’s homes.

ארגון "1 דיי" בשיתף עם מאיה שרון מארגנים לכם מסיבת שבועות בקיו הוטל (הרווחים ממנה ייתרמו לפרוייקט לשיפוץ בתים לניצולי שואה)

Open bar, PRIVATE event (only tickets holders can enter), all you can drink, our own personal DJ and even surprise bags of candy hanging from the ceiling.  

מסיבת שתייה חופשית!!! מסיבה סגורה (רק חברים מוזמנים לאירוע), מוזיקה (בעיקר מיינסטרים, רוק, היפ הופ, ישראלי ועוד) די ג'יי ישראל מייזנר האגדי והפתעות נוספות. 

Where: Q HOTEL; Ha Arba'a 10, Tel Aviv, רחוב הארבעה 10, תל אביב

When: 22/5/2015; Doors open at 22:00 :פתיחת שערים

Music: Mainstream, Israeli, Hip-Hop, Dance and a DJ

Drinks: All you can drink, all night, great quality imported products 

People: You and your friends who wanna come, celebrate, dance and donate to a great cause

To get an idea about Maya's former parties, go to the GALLERY and have a look at some pictures. 

About OneDay:

OneDay is a unique organization that offers flexible and adaptable volunteering opportunities for young adults while increasing their social and professional networks with people their own age.

"1 דיי" הוא ארגון ייחודי אשר מאפשר פלטפורמת התנדבות גמישה, ומאפשרת הזדמנויות להתנדבות עבור חבר'ה צעירים יחד עם יצירת חברויות חדשות עם אנשים בגילאים דומים.

story:
Why I'm  here:

Did I get your attention with the title? Good. That's not what this fundraiser is for. All donations will go to support the work of the UN Women's Organization for equal rights for ALL.
It has recently been brought to my attention (thank you Vox for this article) that women have a HUGE problem, his name is Steven Santagati, and he's an ignorant DudeBrah of epic proportions. Recently this enemy of women's rights  self described gentleman was invited by CNN to speak in response to the media frenzy created by the "Catcalling" video that went viral last week. CNN apparently thought he'd provide an anti-feminist unique perspective, as the NY Times bestselling author of "Bad Boys Finish First." Included in the many ignorant provocative statements he made about women were: 

1. Women like it when they are catcalled, it "builds up our confidence and self esteem."

2. As a man, he knows what men think better than a woman, and as this type of expert he wants you to know that he "knows" how women feel when they are catcalled and how they feel is (see #1 above).

3. If women were catcalled by "handsome" men, they would like it and want it (more than they already do, by his estimation)

Let's #saveSteven and get him to Africa for an education about the oppression of women.

What I want to do:

Borrow a page from my potato-salad-making comrades from the internet and get a campaign to go viral...except all the money will go to the HeforShe campaign's beneficiary: UN Women Organization.

    What could this mean?

    Well beyond the life-changing  effect we could have on thousands of women nationwide who face oppression, we could also make Mr. Santagati see that he behaved like a real buffoon, jackass, ignoramus, jacklehead, moron, entitled last bastion of male privilege.

      Risks & Challenges

      Well I don't think Steven is going to accept my Facebook request if that's what you're asking...

        Other Ways You Can Help

        Give a damn about this conversation and prove it by taking action. If you need inspiration look here.

story:
What's Happening?

My name is Corinne Tobias, author of Wake & Bake: a cookbook. I'm a farmer, writer, photographer, designer and cannabis cook working on an independent publishing project in Colorado. 

This year, after publishing the first Wake & Bake, things got real. If you wan't to know how real, you can read this blog post. But all you really need to know is that I woke up one morning with half of a new cannabis cookbook, without a big fancy celebrity's face to put on it. 

So. Here we are. Let's make Wake & Bake II together. For starters... I need a subtitle. Since you guys are smarter, more clever, and better looking than me, I'll leave that to you. 

Wake & Bake II: Barely Legal?

Wake & Bake II: Still Baked?

Wake & Bake II: Into Dankness? 

Post your suggestions at www.facebook.com/wakeandbakecookbook

or email me at corinne@wakeandbakecookbook.com 

Next, help fund the project. It's what a smart, clever, good looking person would do. In return, I'll mail you some delightful stuff when it's done.

Why?

Your support does more than just help create a cannabis cookbook. It helps sustain an independent alternative publishing project carving out a niche in a new industry, covering a somewhat touchy subject. When I looked into publishing the first Wake & Bake, the national prohibition of cannabis made it untouchable by legitimate publishers, so the book was funded by people like you. I'd like to find a way to continue creating educational, entertaining and engaging books that fill the void in this growing market.

I truly feel that it's my calling to bring this information to a general audience. I've been surprised to hear that many many of my readers are baby boomers who have never tried marijuana before, but have recently become canna-curious. These cookbooks, however silly they may be, seem to break the stigma surrounding cannabis use and provide an approachable way to open up discussion about safe and responsible use and ending cannabis prohibition. 

If we can raise enough to go on a national book tour, I'll be able to talk about the things I'm really passionate about in prohibition states (i.e. healing with cannabis, legalization, and crafting legislation that truly benefits the local economy and organic growers). Help me spread the word!


The Goal

As a brand new start up, we never had the funding to take the first book on tour. 

If we can reach the extended $8000 goal, we can take both books on a national tour! This means that we can get out of our bubble and I'll have the opportunity to talk about legal cannabis and making weed food across the nation. Yay! 

Here's the funding breakdown:

$1000- Releases Wake & Bake: a second edition

$2500- Creates Wake & Bake II

$3000- Makes Wake & Bake II available in Hardcover

$3500- Launches Regional Book Tour (Colorado) 2015

$5500- Launches West Coast Book Tour 2015

$8000- Launches National Book Tour 2015 (email corinne@wakeandbakecookbook.com to request a stop at your dispensary, in your town, or at your favorite festival on the book tour)

And for you?

Check out them Perks! You can choose from digital downloads, advance copies of the book, cannabis cooking classes (via skype or in your Colorado/WA home), Wake & Bake apparel and more! 

If you have a dispensary, head shop, or indie bookstore, claim a stop on the book tour and a bunch of books at a wholesale rate. I'll promote the event at your store, answer questions and sign things! 

    Risks & Challenges

    Cannabis is still illegal in 48 states, and this whole thing can be a bit risky. But attitudes are becoming more relaxed surrounding weed, and I do everything I can to comply with state and local laws. While publishing can be a challenge, I've been through all of the indie publishing hoops and know what to expect this time around, so I expect the process to go a lot more smoothly and quickly. 

    Other Ways You Can Help

    Can't contribute, but you've read all of these words? You can help by helping get the word out. 

    Share the link or use the Indiegogo share tools! 

    Sign up for the newsletter @ https://tinyletter.com/wakeandbakecookbook

    Like Wake & Bake on FB and stay updated for contests, recipes, and info!

story:
PUApill.com - “The real world of dating”

Have you ever spent money on a dating guru’s latest get-the-girl scheme? Or read a book from a self-proclaimed “dating expert” that promises results, but you haven’t seen any outside of wasting your time? Or subscribed to a dating coach that just keeps asking for more subscriptions, though nothing is helping you at all? There’s a lot of people out there that will try to take advantage of people when it comes to their love life, and for the average man or woman, it’s really hard to weed through all the garbage. So how do you go about it? One way is to use online resources such as PUApill.com.

What is PUApill.com? It’s an amazing new website that allows users to access a forum of information and resources devoted to debunking and sorting through the piles of garbage that floats around about relationships and dating. A lot of people make a living out of coaching people in the dating realm, but with a resource like this, those scams hold little water. Seduction schemes can rob people of a lot of money in the end, and in a world where making a quick buck is the most important thing to some people, knowledge is power. What better revenue then free information? PUApill.com show what men really need to have success with women. They don't need to waste their money for expensive bootcamps from self proclaimed Dating Coaches.

What does crowdfunding have to do with this? It takes funding to create a resource like this, and to launch the kind of marketing it takes to get the site the attention it deserves. Part of that is also making the site look more appealing. A better layout would bring in a greater audience, and it would also ensure that the audience that comes in takes the content as seriously as it should be taken. On top of that, the site needs a great deal more functions, and to do that takes time and money. Finally, it takes a lot of money to promote new sites. The internet is a large place, and it takes serious marketing to get noticed. We need money to get the ball rolling, and to match us with the viewers who are really looking for the help we can provide.

By giving to this project, you will be supporting something that will not only inform those looking for genuine help, but it will save people from wasting their lives and money in scams and liars. All supporters will be recognized publicly in the site (if they want) because we believe it is important to acknowledge those who have helped us. Funding this project is more than just a passing whim—it’s going to change the way people view dating and the way others interact with one another when it comes to sharing this kind of information. By giving the power back to the people, it ends scams and money-makers taking advantage of others. That’s the best and most noble mission one could hope for.

story:
We've found a Backer!  But we still need you! Our new goal is $10,000, which is 400 people to contribute $20 to our campaign and the StaySafe Locking Leash will arrive at your home and to stores near you!  Join us in the movement in Pet Security and be one of the first to own a StaySafe Locking Leash!



The Short Of It

My name is Diane, I am the inventor of the patent-pending StaySafe Lock, a lock that looks and functions like a typical snap-hook clip found at the collar end of almost any leash - you push the pin up and down to secure the leash to the collar. 

Now put a combination lock in the shaft of the snap-hook.  Spin the dials and you can't push down the pin.  

My first product, the StaySafe Locking Leash, is meant to be used for safely leaving your dog to grab a coffee to-go or a quick carton of milk, without worrying your dog will be taken.  It incorporates two StaySafe Locks located at either end of a nylon multi-function leash that has a light chain running through, and a very attractive collar-end of round links that can be used with your dogs existing collar, or as a collar, and it is adjustable because of the links.

Why

I came up with the idea for the StaySafe Lock and the StaySafe Locking Leash because of my basset hound Gus.  I loved picking up a morning coffee with him, and the coffee shop I frequented has huge windows where I could see him clearly and easily, but it always bothered me... if I was chatting with someone, and I was distracted even for a minute, a person could easily take him.  The StaySafe Locking Leash is my solution.

The Clams

I am here asking for your contribution towards the development of the StaySafe Lock and the StaySafe Locking Leash.  My funding goal is $45,000, and if you choose so, as a perk for a contribution of $15 (plus $5 shipping) you will receive a StaySafe Locking Leash in your choice of small or medium sizes.  The suggested retail price will be $30+.

To give you a breakdown of how your money will be used, as based off of a $15 contribution:  $10 to manufacture your StaySafe Locking Leash; $5 towards development.  For larger contributions, your money will still be put towards the development of the StaySafe Locking Leash, but it will also pay for prototypes to be used as sales samples.  There are also perks that include a donation to the College of Veterinary Medicine and Biomedical Sciences located in Colorado, of which I urge you to choose.  

What if...

If I don't make my fundraising goal, depending on the amount raised, there are different avenues I can take to continue with the development of the StaySafe Locking Leash, and everyone will get their perk, but it may take longer to get it to your door.  

A Different Impact

For some background.  Two months ago lost my Gus, at the age of 7 1/2 to Congestive Heart Failure (CHF) due to Mitral Valve Disease, a type of heart disease. I was told that there was no cure.  This was not entirely true.

Project CARE, via the Colorado Veterinary College, does research into the causes of CHF, hoping to find a way to mitigate the disease.  They also have a device called the Mitral Seal, which according to their site is ' a curative treatment for dogs with advanced mitral valve disease and heart failure'.  Initially I thought it could have saved my Gus, but it is in the experimental stage.  By selecting a perk that  includes Project Care your money will not only aid in their research, it will also give me the opportunity to network with the Colorado Veterinary College with the goal of bringing this technology to the Guelph Veterinary University here in Ontario.  We have some of the best doctors and researchers in the world located in Canada, they should have the opportunity to make perfect this technique and technology that will save the lives of our canine family members.

I encourage you to look at the Project CARE website to learn more  

http://csu-cvmbs.colostate.edu/vth/small-animal...

So when you contribute to StaySafe Locks, not only will you get a StaySafe Locking Leash, the first of it's kind in the world, you will also be contributing to a very worthwhile cause.

For the Water Cooler 

Spread the word to your friends and family and to whomever you know who loves dogs and help me make getting a morning coffee or a quick carton of milk a much safer and less stressful time for us and our pets.

Images

In case you didn't happen to see the video and are interested in seeing some images of the StaySafe Locking Leash, click on the Gallery tab at the top of the page you'll be there.

For some background.  Two months ago lost my Gus, at the age of 7 1/2 to Congestive Heart Failure (CHF) due to Mitral Valve Disease, a type of heart disease. I was told that there was no cure.  This was not entirely true.
Project CARE, via the Colorado Veterinary College, does research into the causes of CHF, hoping to find a way to mitigate the disease.  They also have a device called the Mitral Seal, which according to their site is ' a curative treatment for dogs with advanced mitral valve disease and heart failure'.  Initially I thought it could have saved my Gus, but it is in the experimental stage.  By selecting a perk that  includes Project Care your money will not only aid in their research, it will also give me the opportunity to network with the Colorado Veterinary College with the goal of bringing this technology to the Guelph Veterinary University here in Ontario.  We have some of the best doctors and researchers in the world located in Canada, they should have the opportunity to make perfect this technique and technology that will save the lives of our canine family members.
I encourage you to look at the Project CARE website to learn more  
http://csu-cvmbs.colostate.edu/vth/small-animal...
So when you contribute to StaySafe Locks, not only will you get a StaySafe Locking Leash, the first of it's kind in the world, you will also be contributing to a very worthwhile cause.
For the Water Cooler 

Spread the word to your friends and family and to whomever you know who loves dogs and help me make getting a morning coffee or a quick carton of milk a much safer and less stressful time for us and our pets.

Images
In case you didn't happen to see the video and are interested in seeing some images of the StaySafe Locking Leash, click on the Gallery tab at the top of the page you'll be there.

story:
Short Summary

I have worked with companion animals for a combined 32 year both personally and professionally in Maryland and Oregon.  My background is in veterinary medicine and kenneling / boarding.  I am trained in the care, handling, medication administration as well the recognition of when pet behavior can be cause for concern.  

Spending the last 15 years in animal care settings has allowed me to get to know many pet owners that want to provide the best care for their pets.  And that extends to offering care, including socialization, medication if needed and company while their family travels.  Whether for a weekend at the coast, a business trip out of state or a family vacation to France; we want to provide the best care for your pets!  We know that your pet is part of your family.  We treat your pets as we do our own! 

As a business owner, offering services part time while working another job has "worked" in the past but that put limitations on how many jobs I could take on.  Now I am looking to expand my business to be able to serve more pet owners in the Portland area and offer round the clock care!  I know many pets don't like to be alone for long hours whether during the work day or when the family is on vacation.  I am looking at adding another employee and building our marketing and advertising campaign.  This will allow When You're Not There Pet Care to provide care for more families that want the very best for their pets including offering medically trained staff and overnight care. 

What We Need:

I am looking to raise $1500 for the growth of my business.  Hiring part time staff, expanding on services, and having a bit more flexibility to pinpoint marketing tools that will draw a larger client base are my immediate goals.  There are many hurdles and costs associated with the expansion of any business.  

I pride myself on being able to structure your pet's visits to their exact needs.  Every pet is an individual and reacts differently to someone other than Mom or Dad taking care of their needs.  I respect this and go at their speed to make them comfortable. 

    Risks & Challenges

    Many of my friends know that I have overcome many personal hurdles in order to do what I love.  I have physical limitations that inhibit me from providing services like  dog walks for large dogs and overnight care for pets due to my bad back.  I know there are folks that need these services and am looking to hire more staff to serve these pet care needs in our community.  

    I am convinced that with your support, When You're Not There Pet Care can grow to be one of Portland's premier and most reliable pet care providers.  I became an entrepreneur back in the late 1990's when I ran one of Portland's first pet taxi services.  I saw a need and took a risk and started Taxi Cat, one of Portland's first taxi and shuttle services for pets.  In addition, I partnered up with a young lady in the late 90's as well to run one of Washington's first Doggy Daycare centers.  Back then, there were very few and the red tape was everywhere!  I know with my past business experience and my "go get it!" attitude, this business venture will thrive!

    Other Ways You Can Help

    Please feel free to share my efforts to grow my petsitting business with your friends and family members that appreciate a small business aiming to exceed their pet care needs!

story:
"More Hummus Less Hamas" was discovered on a clever protest sign at a pro-Israel rally in NYC. Israel is currently fighting for her right to exist in the Middle East. She is defending herself from hundreds of daily missiles launched into highly populated areas by Hamas, purposefully targeting civilians. The radical Islamic terrorist group Hamas, based out of Gaza, is on a mission to eradicate Israel and anything representative of a Democracy. We are asking people who believe in the state of Israel, the only true democracy in that region, to purchase our shirts as we plan to give 100% of the proceeds to families living in Sderot, infamously referred to as "The Bomb Shelter Capital of the World." Whilst Gaza is always in the news, the hardship of those who live in Sderot - 3 km from the Gaza Strip - is wantonly ignored.
The people of Sderot must run to bomb shelters on average 21 times a day.  Imagine doing this with children and the elderly. Schools have closed down, businesses empty, dozens killed and even more injured, and children have had their childhood taken away. Whilst we in the West can take our children outside to the playgrounds, take them to school and let them play football, the children of Sderot can only dream of this. The people of Sderot do not deserve this. Please help US support THEIR community. 
BUY A "MORE HUMMUS LESS HAMAS" T SHIRT TODAY
Please visit http://teespring.com/morehummuslesshamas to buy a T-shirt and contribute to this amazing cause.

story:
Short Summary

The hockey camp, which is free for youth, has been held in Iqaluit, the capital of Nunavut, each summer since 2002. In August 2014, coaches and volunteers welcomed over 120 participants with healthy meals, on- and off-ice training, and team building.

Sadly in 2015, the camp had to be cancelled due to lack of funding, much to the disappointment of children, parents, coaches and volunteers. Jesse Mike, the camp’s coordinator, said, “It’s important for us to continue to provide these services for free to families and children from across Nunavut. We will continue fundraising, creating stronger partnerships with businesses and organizations that provide services in Nunavut and planning so that we can come back, stronger than ever, in 2016.”

What We Need & What You Get

With your support we can:

  • Provide healthy meals to over 100 kids each day for a week.
  • Provide transportation for our awesome volunteers and coaches.
  • In addition to sports activities, the camp offers sessions on fitness, nutrition and team-building. 

The Impact

There's a reason our volunteers and sponsors are so passionate about the camp. We're making a difference: 

The challenges facing kids in the North are significant: the suicide rates for children and teens in the Arctic regions are five times higher than in the rest of the country. 

Programs like the hockey camp aim to make a difference by providing positive experiences and opportunities.

For over a decade, Nunavut Stars Hockey Camp has been giving kids a chance to learn and grow in a safe environment. 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Spread the word! 

    Follow all of the action: http://facebook.com/NunavutStars and @nunavutstarshoc

  • Use Indiegogo's share tools to encourage friends and family to donate to our campaign!

story:
Finally, guiltless nail services!!!!!!

I love doing nails but I adore animals even more.   I just hate that so many cosmetic companies (and most nail salons) don't seem to agree.  There are so many cruelty-free options available now, yet it is nearly impossible to find a salon that considers those options.  This is why I will have to build my own collection of animal friendly products and set up as a stand-alone nail tech in a hair salon.  I have put a lot of research into this and I will continue to do so on a regular basis.  

I not only plan to use cruelty-free polishes and gel polishes but I will also use polishes that are a much safer alternative to traditional polishes as well. So I have found 5-free, 7-free and water-based polishes (great for kiddos and mommas-to-be).  The number you see represents the amount of toxins eliminated from that specific polish.  


I will also use organic lotions and oils that aren't full of the sludge found in most body products.  


I plan purchase an auto-clave as the first “big purchase” if I meet my goal.   It is not required by the State Board of OK,  but I think my clients would feel good knowing my tools are cleaned to the highest degree, literally.


Any files, buffers or nail-scrub brushes that I use on a client will be given to them to take home at the end of the appointment. Yay for free stuff!!!!!!  


No acrylic, dip or wrap systems will be used so no fumes to punch you in the throat and it will minimize a lot of filing dust particles.  Nor will I be in a salon that uses those products.


I will use:

 

hard-gel overlays, as an alternative to acrylic

lacquers (5-free, 7-free, 8-free etc)

gel polish (5-free) 

water-based polishes 

and “naked” manis (which is a mani sans polish) 


I may even be able to get a pipe-less (much more sanitary) pedicure set up with biodegradable, disposable liners.  


This may seem like a lot, but start-up cost for nails is not cheap when you add in the cost of major equipment and used furniture (which I plan to upcycle), polish collections, tools, supplies, implements, products etc.  


Thank you  for your support!!!!!! 

deb

story:
NPC Camp gear has been tossed around long enough! 

Since Ralinwood  changed hands almost 4 years ago, our game has grown so much - more people are attending, more new players are attending, and even better, more people want to NPC and Shape! Even better, we moved to a new site, with many fancy amenities. Even more better, over the years, NPC camp's inventory has grown and grown.  And grown. And with more stuff and a new site comes a great need for a place to keep all this gear close by. 

So, with the support and approval of Global, the support some of some wonderful donors and sponsors, and the enthusiasm of the new site (who have already cut open a space for the shed)... we are looking to buy Ralinwood a new shed!

What are we getting:

If we hit the target, we will be getting a 20' Sea Can shipping container. It's marketed as being water-tight (as it goes to sea, hopefully this is accurate), weather-proof, animal-proof, and best of all, comes with a door that is unlikely to break (again, we hope). The funds we are raising will also include the cost to have it delivered and installed, so once the funds are all collected, all we need to do it order and point. If we can get a Sea Can, we will be offering 'berths' for players to rent. What are berths you ask? Berths (for the purpose of this fundraiser) are spaces you can rent on a shelf in the shed. You must supply your own container, but we will give you the space for one large (30Gal) and one small plastic containers inside the shed for the whole season, with an option to store over the winter. 

If we hit something less than the target, we will still be getting a shed, but something a little smaller. We don't know what yet, so we will look at if we can't reach the target. We do expect a smaller shed will not leave room for berths.

Shed Install / Build Day:

Once we have raised the funds, we will arrange a day for delivery with the site and host a 'build day' / OOG social to get NPC camp's gear moved in, paint the shed/sea can, and generally get together to hang out and celebrate. That date is TBD!

Funding Deadline: Sooner!

We are hoping to have funds raised within a few months, but we understand that it may take some time. New site is very patient and willing to work with us until we can get the funds together, but sooner is better for everyone!

Appreciation

We'd like to sincerely thank everyone who has offered to contribute a 'prize' the fundraiser. Every one of you is amazing and we cannot thank you enough.

Thank-you to Birdee Blake for the poster!

Thank-you to Dave and Ted for working with us to approve the fundraiser items.

And of course, thank-YOU all, both for reading this whole post, and for being a part of Ralinwood. We are doing this for you! And somewhat so Jade and Matty don't have to haul gear between sites anymore. But MOSTLY for you, the players, the NPCs, Ralinwood.

story:
Our guarantee: 100% of contributions we receive will be used to pay for the health and safety-related construction upgrades described on this page.

We are continuing with our Kresge funded grant project. Over the next 3 years, we will make 120 homes green, safe and healthy.

We need your help. We have about $1500 to put in each of these homes. We need donations of labor, supplies and dollars to add to each of these homes.

The mold in Ms. Bullion’s home has wreaked havoc on the air that her family breathes. Her 17 year-old has been to doctor three times in the past month, and her 7 year-old is now on an inhaler. Though she was intent on expressing her concerns for her children’s health, after some time Ms. Bullion let us know that she had gone to see her doctor three times in past month as well.

Moisture from the upstairs bathroom has weakened the floor underneath it, and is now leaking downstairs at a constant drip causing mold growth on long stretches of the basement walls and in tucked away corners and inaccessible spaces. Due to the substantial amount of mold growth, she was forced to remove the walls of her basement bathroom along with any existing carpet rendering it uninhabitable.

Poor ventilation is also an issue in the Bullion home. There are no vents in her kitchen or bathroom creating excessive moisture throughout her home, exacerbating the asthma symptoms for her and her children. In addition to the myriad of concerns in the interior of the home, missing gutters, and the deterioration of the soil surrounding Ms. Bullion’s foundation is also allowing water to seep into the basement, facilitating the mold growth that the family has attempted to address.

We need any help we can find to make this home a safe and healthy environment for Ms. Bullion and her children. Please feel free to contact us, we would welcome any donation you might be able to afford.


We are also seeking donations of labor and supplies. If you are able to donate these please contact clayton@omahahealthykids.org

story:
(From Phil Wheeler)

 

Debbie and I have known each other all our lives.  We grew up in the same church in Euclid, Ohio and attended the same youth groups.  Debbie attended Euclid HS, I did not, but we still saw each other just about every Sunday.  I joined the Navy out of High School, and Debbie went to work.  We never dated, we were just two kids who knew each other.  I would come home on leave, and I might see her, but we didn't communicate during my stint in the military.

 

I got out in 1973, and returned home for a couple of months before leaving to attend college at Miami University of Ohio.  I happen to be walking through the basement of our church, and I saw Debbie standing and teaching some young children.  She was wearing a black velvet skirt, a blouse with old fashioned ruffles down the front, and a ruffled collar with a black ribbon.  A broach was pinned to that ribbon.  I looked at her and said to myself That is the girl I am going to marry!  We were married a little over 9 months later. 

 

We moved into an apartment, then a house, and then another house, while I went to school to learn how to fix computers.  I was hired by Memorex, and we moved to Akron, Ohio.  We bought our dream house (we still live there), and planned to start a family.  Unfortunately, our 5-year plan became a 7-year plan.  Once we figured out how to do it, though, we started having babies.  First, 3 daughters, and finally 2 sons – Rachel, Abigail, Hannah, Joshua, and Joseph.  They are all grown now, and two are married.  We have 3 grandchildren – 2 girls, and a boy.

 

It all sounds pretty idyllic, but in 1993 Debbie was first diagnosed with breast cancer and our lives changed forever.  She had a modified radical mastectomy, chemotherapy,  and later had reconstruction.    We continued on, trying to put it behind us, but nothing is ever the same after cancer strikes.   

 

In 1999 the cancer came back.  Chemotherapy, again, and a decision about a possible bone marrow transplant followed.     She was given a less than 40% chance of survival, but God performed a miracle.  The tests came back clear, and she was in remission.

 

In 2008 she again was stricken.  Chemotherapy and radiation followed, but the doctor said that it was only a matter of time, and she was given 3-4 years to live.  From that point in time to the present there has been a consent repeated pattern of treatment and cessation, treatment and cessation as the  cancer had metastasized, spreading to her liver and bones.

 

The chemotherapy has taken her hair (twice), made her feet and hands raw, red and painful, and robbed her of her energy.  Through if all she has continued to work as a teachers aid for the High School, and endured. 

 

This past week, however, the tests came back and for the first time the doctor told Debbie that she has maybe 6 months to live.  She did not hold out any hope as she has in the past, she said Worst case scenario is 6 months, but didn't feel like it would be much more, regardless.

 

Through this, my wife has been a source of amazement and encouragement to others in our church and the school system where she works.  I see both sides.  The one that is smiling and never letting on how tired she is or how sore her hands and feet are, and the side where she is falling asleep on the sofa right after dinner or picking off the dead skin on her hands and feet.  Each day she is a little more run down, a little weaker and less able to recover from the constant attack on her system by the cancer and by the chemotherapy. I have been watching her die slowly.  I must admit that I haven't always been the best care giver, sometimes she can be down right cranky, but I am still here.

 

We have been married for 38 years, 39 years September 7th, and for all of those 38 years she has always talked about going on a cruise.  I joke that I was on a couple in the Navy, and they weren't that big a deal.  Unfortunately, something has always stood in the way.  Kids need clothing, and cars break, the house needs fixing, or we just didn't have the time.  Now, I don't have the money to make it happen.  I lost my job, and we had to file for bankruptcy.  I never thought that I would be saying any of this at 61 years of age, but that's the way it is.  The good news is that I have just been hired as a custodian at a local church, and start Monday.  It's part-time, and I will continue to look for full-time employment. 

 

I have contacted various organizations about Debbie's desire.  The make a wish foundation doesn't provide cruises, nor does the Angel foundation.  I attend a small church and have talked with my pastor, and he is talking to certain members.  I don't know what to expect, but I believe that they will help as much as they can; The economy in Ohio isn’t the best.
story_txt:
(From Phil Wheeler)
 
Debbie and I have known each other all our lives.  We grew up in the same church in Euclid, Ohio and attended the same youth groups.  Debbie attended Euclid HS, I did not, but we still saw each other just about every Sunday.  I joined the Navy out of High School, and Debbie went to work.  We never dated, we were just two kids who knew each other.  I would come home on leave, and I might see her, but we didn't communicate during my stint in the military.
 
I got out in 1973, and returned home for a couple of months before leaving to attend college at Miami University of Ohio.  I happen to be walking through the basement of our church, and I saw Debbie standing and teaching some young children.  She was wearing a black velvet skirt, a blouse with old fashioned ruffles down the front, and a ruffled collar with a black ribbon.  A broach was pinned to that ribbon.  I looked at her and said to myself That is the girl I am going to marry!  We were married a little over 9 months later. 
 
We moved into an apartment, then a house, and then another house, while I went to school to learn how to fix computers.  I was hired by Memorex, and we moved to Akron, Ohio.  We bought our dream house (we still live there), and planned to start a family.  Unfortunately, our 5-year plan became a 7-year plan.  Once we figured out how to do it, though, we started having babies.  First, 3 daughters, and finally 2 sons – Rachel, Abigail, Hannah, Joshua, and Joseph.  They are all grown now, and two are married.  We have 3 grandchildren – 2 girls, and a boy.
 
It all sounds pretty idyllic, but in 1993 Debbie was first diagnosed with breast cancer and our lives changed forever.  She had a modified radical mastectomy, chemotherapy,  and later had reconstruction.    We continued on, trying to put it behind us, but nothing is ever the same after cancer strikes.   
 
In 1999 the cancer came back.  Chemotherapy, again, and a decision about a possible bone marrow transplant followed.     She was given a less than 40% chance of survival, but God performed a miracle.  The tests came back clear, and she was in remission.
 
In 2008 she again was stricken.  Chemotherapy and radiation followed, but the doctor said that it was only a matter of time, and she was given 3-4 years to live.  From that point in time to the present there has been a consent repeated pattern of treatment and cessation, treatment and cessation as the  cancer had metastasized, spreading to her liver and bones.
 
The chemotherapy has taken her hair (twice), made her feet and hands raw, red and painful, and robbed her of her energy.  Through if all she has continued to work as a teachers aid for the High School, and endured. 
 
This past week, however, the tests came back and for the first time the doctor told Debbie that she has maybe 6 months to live.  She did not hold out any hope as she has in the past, she said Worst case scenario is 6 months, but didn't feel like it would be much more, regardless.
 
Through this, my wife has been a source of amazement and encouragement to others in our church and the school system where she works.  I see both sides.  The one that is smiling and never letting on how tired she is or how sore her hands and feet are, and the side where she is falling asleep on the sofa right after dinner or picking off the dead skin on her hands and feet.  Each day she is a little more run down, a little weaker and less able to recover from the constant attack on her system by the cancer and by the chemotherapy. I have been watching her die slowly.  I must admit that I haven't always been the best care giver, sometimes she can be down right cranky, but I am still here.
 
We have been married for 38 years, 39 years September 7th, and for all of those 38 years she has always talked about going on a cruise.  I joke that I was on a couple in the Navy, and they weren't that big a deal.  Unfortunately, something has always stood in the way.  Kids need clothing, and cars break, the house needs fixing, or we just didn't have the time.  Now, I don't have the money to make it happen.  I lost my job, and we had to file for bankruptcy.  I never thought that I would be saying any of this at 61 years of age, but that's the way it is.  The good news is that I have just been hired as a custodian at a local church, and start Monday.  It's part-time, and I will continue to look for full-time employment. 
 
I have contacted various organizations about Debbie's desire.  The make a wish foundation doesn't provide cruises, nor does the Angel foundation.  I attend a small church and have talked with my pastor, and he is talking to certain members.  I don't know what to expect, but I believe that they will help as much as they can; The economy in Ohio isn’t the best.

story:
That's it! I'm at capacity!
Thank you, everyone!

We're going to have an amazing night (with lasers!)

 

Oct 3 Update (New Video + Logo!)

New Video! 
http://youtu.be/va0bZ12UYsY?hd=1

And to answer a few questions...

Tickets will NOT be sold at the door.
Costumes are definitely welcome!
The Party Logo is finished!! This is printed on the cups, shirts, and hoodies...

 

The Details

I'm turning 30 this year! To celebrate, I'm hosting the biggest, best Halloween party that Seattle has ever seen - and you and your friends are invited! This is going down on the evening of Saturday, October 27th.

Come help me celebrate and be there for a night that won't be forgotten. And like any good Birthday Halloween party, costumes are welcome! 

If you can't make it, at least help me put the party on by gifting $10 or by buying one of the perks and be forever recognized on the Offical Party Poster! 

What I Need & What You Get

For only $20 you'll get entry into the party + unlimited alcohol. Let me say that again, O-P-E-N bar. Many bars and clubs charge upwards of $30 just for cover during Halloween weekend and they won't include drinks. You'll also get a sweet HD wallpaper from the party and props for helping to make this a reality.

Additional dontions will earn you awesome swag, such as:

  • The Official Party Poster
  • A sweet light-up cup for the party (really, really awesome)
  • T-shirts! [including sizes for girls!]
  • Warm and cozy hoodies
  • A limo ride and party package for you and 7 friends!

What The Money Will Buy

I'm really going all out, and every cent will go toward the party. You've never been to a party like this. Here's what I'm spending the money on:

With $4000:

  • The Venue - At a beautiful brick building built nearly 100 years ago
  • Alcohol - Including beer, red and white wine, and hard alcohol
  • Mixers, water, ice, cups, napkins, and other miscellaneous party supplies
  • Security - People don't mess with off-duty police officers
  • Bartenders - Professionals make better drinks
  • Projector - Showing Saturday morning cartoons, PBS, TGIF, and other classics
  • Sound Equipment - A party isn't a party without good dance music
  • Insurance - Required for a party of this size
  • Licenses - Again, required for a party of this size
  • Fees - To cover IndieGoGo and my ticketing vendor

That's the minimum I need to put the party on. BUT! With a few hundred bucks extra I can do even more! Here's my ideal scenario:

With $5600:

  • Laser Beams - One needs a license from the FDA to operate a Class 3b/4 laser system. Guess who applied for a license months ago? Now I just need money to buy the equipment and software.
  • Fog Machines - A laser is only as good as the fog in the air
  • Bubble Fogger - Imagine a bubble machine that fills the bubbles with fog instead of air. More fun to pop!
  • Johann Sebastian Joust - Super fun game that uses the Playstation Move controllers and music - no PS3 needed. Requires 7 PS Move Controllers (anyone have some I can borrow??)

How Else Can I Help?

Tell your friends! Did I mention that they're invited, too? 

Note: You must be 21 and older with a valid ID to enter the party.

story:
My name is Randy and I am a community volunteer and small business owner. I have been an entrepreneur all of my life.  I was born and raised in a small town in Arkansas and have always enjoyed small town America. When I was 18 I joined the Marine Corps as a way to earn money for college. After spending 8 years serving our country I got out and started college. I earned a BS in Computer Science and later a MBA. Once I was done with school I started volunteering in the small town I now call my home. My wife and I have decided this is where we want to raise our children and watch our grandchildren grow up. 

Once I started volunteering I realized how hard it is for small towns to get the technology they need to meet their residents expectations, stay current, and provide the services that they would like to. Since I have a background as a software developer I decided I would look and see what I could do. That searching has turned into this larger project I want to share with you. 

I am building a software package that will help small cities manage many of the tasks that they deal with daily. There are two separate modules; Code Enforcer and Asset Manager. Code Enforcer will help manage the following city activities: Site Plans, Plats, Conditional Use Permits, Rezoning, Annexation, Variances, Business Licenses and Municipal Ordinances. 

Asset Manager will allow the cities assets to be listed by department and be assigned a depreciation value. At any time a resident can walk in and ask to see assets of the city by department and an estimated value. It will also allow cities to track any public property that has been sent to be recycled.

I thought that I was going to be able to write, test and implement this by myself and that is now clear I will not be able to do that. I have brought in a professional Java Architect to help me finish this project. He is willing to lower his standard rate because he also sees the need and wants to help but I still need additional funding. 

I want to put my skills to use for the greater good. My goal is to get solid enterprise level software tools in the hands of small town America. Once the software is completed I would like to set up committee and I would give away 1 install per quarter to a small town that shows a need through an application process. The municipalities that can afford a small fee can buy our software at a greatly reduced price compared to the other vendors.
